turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Corpse paint.
turn.2: Corpse paint Corpse paint or corpsepaint is a style of black and white makeup used by black metal bands for concerts and band photos.
turn.4: The makeup is used to make the musicians appear inhuman, corpse-like, or demonic, and is perhaps "the most identifiable aspect of the black metal aesthetic." Corpse paint typically involves making the face and neck white and making the area around the eyes and lips black.
turn.5: Did anyone from the band ever get injured?
turn.6: Musicians will often have a trademark style.
turn.7: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.8: Other colors are seldom used, yet there are notable exceptions, such as Attila Csihar's use of neon colors and the bands Satyricon and Dødheimsgard experimenting with color as well.
turn.9: Did they use the paint for anything else?
turn.10: Outside of black metal, face-painting has been used by a variety of other public figures such as shock rock artists (notably Arthur Brown, Alice Cooper, KISS, and members of the Misfits) and professional wrestlers (e.g. Sting and Vampiro).
turn.11: When did they start using it?
turn.12: The earliest rock groups to wear makeup similar to corpse paint included Screamin' Jay Hawkins and Arthur Brown in the 1960s; Secos & Molhados, Alice Cooper and KISS in the 1970s; and later that decade, punk rock bands like the Misfits and singer David Vanian of The Damned.
